[[image:William Henry Pope.jpg|thumb|William Henry Pope]] '''William Henry Pope''' was a [[Canada|Canadian]] lawyer, politician, judge and one of the [[Father_of_Confederation#Fathers_of_Confederation|Fathers of Confederation]]. He was born in [[Bedeque|Bedeque, P.E.I.(Prince Edward Island)]], the son of [[Joseph Pope (politician)|Joseph Pope]] and Lucy Colledge. The editor of [[Prince Edward Island]]'s main [[Tory]] newspaper, ''The Islander'', from 1859 to 1872, he entered politics in 1863. An enthusiastic supporter of [[Canadian Confederation]], he left the PEI cabinet in 1866 but continued to press for union. After this was accomplished in 1873 under the leadership of his brother, PEI Premier [[James Colledge Pope]], he was appointed a county court judge. Ardgowan, Pope's residence, was designated a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site of Canada]] in 1966.<ref>{{CRHP|1160|Ardgowan|18 September 2011}}</ref> During the [[Charlottetown Conference]], the Popes billetted [[George Brown (Canadian politician)|George Brown]] and hosted a luncheon for delegates at Ardgowan. == References == {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Cite DCB|ID=5212 |name=William Henry Pope}} {{Authority control|VIAF=68673987}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Pope, William Henry | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1825 | PLACE OF BIRTH =Bedeque | DATE OF DEATH = 1879 | PLACE OF DEATH =St. Eleanors }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pope, William Henry}} [[Category:1825 births]] [[Category:1879 deaths]] [[Category:Fathers of Confederation]] [[Category:Persons of National Historic Significance (Canada)]] {{PrinceEdwardIsland-politician-stub}}
